body.p: It is only four o'clock; but it is winter and the sun has already set. There are no clouds in the clear, frosty sky to reflect its giant beams, but the air itself is tinged with a slight wreate colour which is again reflected on the snow that covers the groud. I live in a lone cottage on a solitary, wide heath: no voice of life reaches me. I see the desolate plain covered with white, save a few black patches that the noonday sun has made at the top of those sharp pointed hillocks on from which the snow, shiny as it fell, by thinner than on the plain ground: a few birds are pecking at the hard ice that covers the pools— for the frost has been of long continuance

I am in a mathilda strange state of mind. I am alone—quite alone—in the world. The blight of misfortune has hovered over me and withered me. I know that I am about to die and yet I feel happy—joyious—I feel.—. I feel my pulse; its beats fast: I place my thin hand on my cheek; it burns: there is a slight, quick spirit within one which is now emitting its last sparks. I shall never see the snows of another winter—I do believe that I shall v never again feel the urging warmth of another summer sun; and it is on this per- onasionthat I begin to write my tragic history. Perhaps a history such as mine had better die with me, but an feeling that I cannot define leads me on and I am too weak both in body and mind to resist ang the slightest mmgdre while life was strong within me thought indeed that there was a sacred horror in my tale that rendered it unfit for utterance, and now about to die I pollute its mystic terrors. It is as the wood of the Eumenides none but the dying may enter and corpus is about to lie.

What am I writing :— I must collect my thoughts. I do not know that any will peruse these pages except you, my friend, who will recieve them at my death. I do not addep them to you alone because it will give me pleasure to open wpon vrea uoae guenavin in a wal that would be needless if you alone read what I shall write. I shall relate my love therefore as if it were I wrote for strangers. You have often asked me the course of my solitary life; my tears; and above all of my impenetrableand unaffected unkind silence. In life I dared not; I in death I unveil the mystery. Others will top these pages highly over: to you, Woodville, kind, affectionate friend, they will be dear—the precious memorals of a heart-broken girl who, dying, is still wounded by gratitude towards you. Your tears will fall on the words that record my misfortunes; I know they will—and while I have life thank you for your sympathy.
